citeinfo.title: Groundwater nitrate data and ascii grids of predicted nitrate and model inputs for the Central Valley aquifer, California, USA

citeinfo.origin: Katherine M. Ransom; University of California, Davis
Andrew M. Bell; University of California, Davis
David C. Wheeler; Virginia Commonwealth University
George Kourakos; University of California, Davis
Thomas Harter; University of California, Davis
citeinfo.title: A hybrid machine learning model to predict and visualize nitrate concentration throughout the Central Valley aquifer, California, USA

serinfo.sername: Science of the Total Environment Journal

descript.abstract: This public data release contains two ascii grids comprising predicted nitrate concentrations (as NO3-N, mg/L) at two depth zones associated with private and public drinking water supply wells, respectively, in the Central Valley, California; raster files of the 25 predictor variables in the final statistical model; and groundwater nitrate data from the sampled wells used to train and test the model. Both prediction grids are bound by the alluvial bed boundary that defines the Central Valley. The prediction grids were produced with Boosted Regression Tree (BRT) modeling methods within a statistical modeling framework using the statistical modeling software R (R Core Team, https://www.r-project.org/) and linear interpolation within Oasis Montaj software (Geosoft, version 9.0.2). The response variable was a set of nitrate concentrations in wells located within the Central Valley. We compiled the database of well nitrate measurements from private supply and public supply wells. Nitrate data came from two sources, the University of California at Davis (UC Davis) and the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS). Prior to statistical modeling, wells were spatially declustered using an equal area grid cell approach to reduce effects on the modeling of oversampling in areas of intensive agricultural land use. A total of 5170 wells were selected, 3508 of which were used for training and 1662 of which served as hold-out. A database of 25 predictor variables was used for the final BRT model and included well characteristics, land use, climate, soil properties, aquifer properties, depth to the water table, and estimates of nitrogen loading and groundwater age. Based on the gridded predictor variables and final model, nitrate predictions were made using the R raster package for 17 depth zones spaced throughout the aquifer (at 15.24, 30.48, 45.72, 60.96, 76.20, 91.44, 106.68, 121.92, 152.40, 182.88, 213.36, 243.84, 274.32, 304.80, 365.76, 426.72, and 487.68 m below ground surface) to create input layers for 3D mapping with Oasis Montaj software version 9.0.2 (GeoSoft, Inc., 2016). The nitrate prediction grids for each of the 17 depth zones were imported into the Oasis Montaj mapping environment software for 3D interpolation and visualization. Each grid was assigned a vertical thickness of 1 m and linear interpolation was used between each of the layers at a vertical resolution of 1 m to produce a complete representation of predicted nitrate concentration at depth throughout the Central Valley. For visualization purposes, nitrate predictions were extracted from the interpolated model at 54.86 m and at 121.92 m deep. These depths correspond to the average total depths of private and public wells for the training wells.
descript.purpose: Because private wells are not regulated in California, it is important to determine high risk and high priority areas in order to focus future outreach and educational efforts aimed at private well owners. Public supply wells also are at risk, and the cost of treating contaminated groundwater or relocating such wells is high, especially for low-income or disadvantaged communities.

idinfo.accconst: None. Please see 'Distribution Info' for details.
idinfo.useconst: None. Users are advised to read the data set's metadata thoroughly to understand appropriate use and data limitations.
idinfo.native: Environment as of Metadata Creation: Microsoft Windows 7 Version 6.1 (Build 7601) Service Pack 1; Esri ArcGIS 10.3.1 (Build 4959) Service Pack N/A (Build N/A)

attracc.attraccr: The internal model archive exactly reproduces predicted nitrate concentration for training and holdout wells. Some grid cell predictions for rasters imported into OASIS Montaj may vary slightly due to inconsistencies in the way the raster package predict function handled factor variables in the version of the package used for this study. OASIS Montaj was used for 3D visualization at the scale of the Central Valley and the discrepancy does not affect predictions by the boosted regression tree model outside of the raster package, for example to wells at specific locations.

dataqual.logic: No formal logical accuracy tests were conducted.
dataqual.complete: For the UCD data portion of the well nitrate measurements, when multiple wells were assigned to the same location within the dataset, one well was randomly chosen to represent that location. See Ransom, K. M., Bell, A. M., Barber, Q. E., Kourakos, G., and Harter, T.: A Bayesian Approach to Infer Nitrogen Loading Rates from Crop and Landuse Types Surrounding Private Wells in the Central Valley, California, Hydrol. Earth Syst. Sci. Discuss., doi:10.5194/hess-2017-39, in review, 2017.

horizpa.horizpar: A formal accuracy assessment of the horizontal positional information in the data set has not been conducted.

vertacc.vertaccr: A formal accuracy assessment of the vertical positional information in the data set has either not been conducted, or is not applicable.

procstep.procdesc: Processing Step1: Compile well database and spatially decluster wells, select training and testing wells. We compiled the database of well nitrate measurements from private supply and public supply wells. Nitrate data came from two sources, the University of California at Davis (UC Davis) and the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS). Prior to statistical modeling, wells were spatially declustered using an equal area grid cell approach to reduce effects on the modeling of oversampling in areas of intensive agricultural land use. A total of 5170 wells were selected, 3508 of which were used for training and 1662 of which served as hold-out. These steps were performed with a combination of R and SAS statistical modeling software (versions 3.3.1 and 9.4, respectively).

Processing Step 2: Assign all 145 predictor variables to all wells and impute missing values. A database of 145 predictor variables was compiled from a combination of well construction data, GIS attributes and outputs of previous models, including well characteristics (physical and location based), land use, climate, soil properties, aquifer properties, depth to the water table, and estimates of nitrogen loading based on county-scale data. Well characteristics were either provided in each of the well databases (as was the case for use of water at the well), assigned (e.g. latitude, longitude, well depth zone), or calculated (e.g. distance to nearest major river). Wells were assigned to shallow (private well) or deep (public-supply) zones based on measured depth below ground surface to the bottom of the well screen. The 75th percentile well depth was 82.99 m for domestic wells and the 25th percentile depth was 84.73 m for public supply wells; therefore a depth of 82.30 m was used to divide the shallow and deep aquifer zones. Wells lacking measured well depth were assigned to shallow or deep zones based on water use, with domestic and monitoring wells designated shallow and public supply and irrigation wells designated deep. Depth to top and bottom of well screened interval was estimated for these wells based on information from wells with construction data so that well construction characteristics were available for each well and could be tested as predictor variables in the BRT model. This was done by kriging depth to top and bottom of well screened interval for domestic and public supply wells with construction data, respectively, and then extracting this information to all wells based on their assigned depth zone (Bryant Jurgens, U.S. Geological Survey, written communication, 2016, digital data set). Historical and current land use data is from the California Augmented Multi-Source Land use (CAML) 50 m resolution maps based on 5 time periods at approximately 15 year intervals over the past 70 years. Land use surrounding wells was classified for each of the CAML maps for each of the time periods: 1945, 1960, 1975, 1990, and 2005. The CAML land use categories were reclassified into 13 groups based on similarity in land use or crop type. Temperature and rainfall data are from the WorldClim BioClim 1 km resolution layers generated through interpolation of average monthly climate data from weather stations, representative of 1950-2000. The BioClim dataset contains 19 parameters including annual precipitation and precipitation of the wettest and driest month. Soil characteristics, hydrologic group, and drainage class predictor variables are from the Soil Survey Geographic database (SSURGO) which is produced by the Natural Resources Conservation Service (NRCS). Estimates of nitrogen loading from farm and non-farm fertilizer were based on county-wide fertilizer expenditures, and groundwater recharge was derived from base-flow index and mean annual runoff values. In addition to the above attributes, model outputs that included estimations of aquifer physical characteristics were used as predictor variables, as part of the hybrid modeling approach. Model estimated physical aquifer properties include monthly vertical groundwater flux in the upper active CVHM layer (for water year 1999-2000), depth below ground surface to the water table, average estimated percent coarse material in the upper active layer, historical and current field-scale unsaturated zone nitrogen flux estimates for five time periods at 15 year intervals, and groundwater age at the well screen. We calculated a normalized field-scale nitrogen mass balance for each of the time periods where GNLM data were available. Previous statistical model outputs used as predictor variables include BRT-predicted probability of anoxic groundwater and probability of high groundwater manganese concentration (“redox” variables indicating reducing conditions), and kriged depth below ground surface to 60 year old groundwater at the well, based on lumped parameter modeling. Average groundwater age at the well screen for all wells prior to spatial declustering was calculated based on CVHM/MODPATH simulations performed for this study. Three particles were used for each well (at the top, middle, and bottom of well screen) and the average of the three travel times was assigned to each well. All predictor variables were processed in ArcGIS (version 10.3.1), SAS (version 9.4), or in the R computing environment for assignment to wells by either point extract or by statistics within an approximate well source area. A 500 m radius circular well buffer was used for variables that required an approximate well source area for attribution. Well buffers are reasonable surrogates for contributing areas to wells in the Central Valley when the actual contributing area is unknown. Spatial analysis of land use within a range of buffer sizes has indicated 500 radius buffer size is appropriate for attributing land use data to wells in the Central Valley. BRT-predicted redox variables varied by depth increments and were assigned to wells based on median measured depth to the midpoint of the well screen for domestic and public supply wells before data declustering (48.77 and 89.92 m, respectively). Redox predictions at depths of 45.72 and 91.44 m were assigned to shallow and deep wells, respectively. Missing predictor variable values at wells were estimated using the R package caret by the “bag impute” method which fits a bagged tree model for each predictor as a function of all the others. The gbm package was used to perform BRT modeling. Model predictor ArcGIS raster layers selected for the final model were assigned to 1 km grids. Based on the gridded predictor variables and final model, nitrate predictions were made using the R raster package for 17 depth zones spaced throughout the aquifer (at 15.24, 30.48, 45.72, 60.96, 76.20, 91.44, 106.68, 121.92, 152.40, 182.88, 213.36, 243.84, 274.32, 304.80, 365.76, 426.72, and 487.68 m below ground surface) to create input layers for 3D mapping in Oasis Montaj (Geosoft, version 9.0.2). Based on measured well depths of private and public supply wells before data declustering, screen length was set to 12.19 m for depth increments less than 82.30 m (shallow) and to 64.01 m for depths greater than 82.30 m (deep). A hypothetical depth to bottom of screened interval was assumed by centering the average screen length for each respective depth zone (either shallow or deep) on the vertical centroid location of each prediction grid depth. Water use was set to H (private) and P (public supply), respectively, for BRT predictions at shallow and deep depths. Redox variables, average groundwater age at the well screen, use of water at the well, screen length, and depth to bottom of screened interval varied with depth zone. Other predictors, such as soil properties and total N input at the land surface, selected for the final model did not vary with depth.

Processing Step 3: Perform CV tuning and final model variable selection. Prior researchers used regularization to improve the predictive performance of BRT through adjustment of selected parameters such as the number of trees in the ensemble. Along these lines, we used BRT within a statistical learning framework that systematically adjusts tuning parameters referred to here as “metaparameters,” to control for potential overfit by the BRT models and to maximize prediction accuracy. Adjusted metaparameters included the number of trees, interaction depth, and shrinkage. The minimum number of observations in each tree’s terminal nodes was held constant at 10. Ten-fold cross validation tuning was performed on the training dataset with the full list of 145 predictor variables for each combination of a range of each of the metaparameter values using the R package caret. The selected ranges for each metaparameter yielded 900 possible combinations and the “best” combination of metaparameters was selected based on minimum cross validation root mean square error (RMSE), which represents the expected testing error. Cross validation (CV) tuning run time was approximately 16 hours on an Intel Core I-5 4670 processor with 16 GB of 1600 MHz DDR3 RAM. The full BRT model consisting of all 145 predictor variables was then re-fitted with the best CV tuned parameters to all 3508 training observations. Predictor variables were sorted in descending order by relative importance score, which is an estimate of predictor variable influence in the model. Predictors were removed from the minimum RMSE model one-at-a-time until the percent difference in RMSE for hold-out data, compared to the full model with all 145 predictors, consistently exceeded about 1%. We further refined the model to remove redundant variables (such as atmospheric nitrogen input for 1992, which is included in the total nitrogen input for 1992 variable) and to include others desirable for interpretation purposes, while maintaining fit to hold-out data.

Processing Step 4: Register all 25 final variables to ASCII grids to be used for prediction including CVHM groundwater age estimates). A database of 25 predictor variables was used for the final BRT model and included the following variables names: "DTW60YrJurgens", Ngw_1975", "ProbDOpt5ppm", ProbMn50ppb", "CAML1990_natural_water", RiverDist_NEAR", "PrecipMinusETin_1971_2000_GWRP", "CVHM_TextZone", "WaterUse2", "ScreenLength", "LateralPosition", "Age_yrs", PctCoarseMFUpActLayer", MFDTWSpr2000Faunt", "AVG_CLAY", "PBot_krig", "HydGrp_C", "N_total","BioClim_BIO12", HiWatTabDepMin", "AVG_SILT", "AVG_POR", "RechargeAnnualmmWolock", "MFVelSept2000", "MFVelFeb2000". Each of the 25 variables were registered to an ASCII grid representing the continuous coverage values of that variable at each of the 17 depth zones. Most variables did not vary with depth, such as the soil characteristics. In these cases the same ASCII grids were used for each of the 17 depths.

Processing Step 5: Compute predictions, import into Oasis, and perform interpolation and extraction steps. Based on the gridded predictor variables and final model, nitrate predictions were made using the R raster package for 17 depth zones spaced throughout the aquifer (at 15.24, 30.48, 45.72, 60.96, 76.20, 91.44, 106.68, 121.92, 152.40, 182.88, 213.36, 243.84, 274.32, 304.80, 365.76, 426.72, and 487.68 m below ground surface) to create input layers for 3D mapping with Oasis Montaj software version 9.0.2 (GeoSoft, Inc., 2016). The nitrate prediction grids for each of the 17 depth zones were imported into the Oasis Montaj mapping environment software for 3D interpolation and visualization. Each grid was assigned a vertical thickness of 1 m and linear interpolation was used between each of the layers at a vertical resolution of 1 m to produce a complete representation of predicted nitrate concentration at depth throughout the Central Valley. For visualization purposes, nitrate predictions were extracted from the interpolated model at 54.86 m and at 121.92 m deep. These depths correspond to the average total depths of private and public wells for the training wells. These two layers are the final data release outputs.

enttyp.enttypd: Table containing attribute information associated with the data set.

attr.attrdef: Predicted distributions of nitrate at the domestic supply depth (180 feet below land surface) within the alluvial boundary of the Central Valley. Numerical values represent continuous nitrate in groundwater at the domestic supply drinking water depth in the Central Valley, California. File is an ASCII array with header information for number of columns and rows, lower left corner coordinates, and cellsize. See array_projection_information.prj for coordinate system information.
attr.attrdefs: Modeled value

attr.attrdef: Predicted distributions of nitrate at the public supply depth (400 feet below land surface) within the alluvial boundary of the Central Valley. Numerical values represent continuous nitrate in groundwater at the public supply drinking water depth in the Central Valley, California. File is an ASCII array with header information for number of columns and rows, lower left corner coordinates, and cellsize. See array_projection_information.prj for coordinate system information.
attr.attrdefs: Modeled value

attr.attrdef: Average groundwater age at well screen of 50 feet based on CVHM/MODPATH simulations. File is an ASCII array with header information for number of columns and rows, lower left corner coordinates, and cellsize. See array_projection_information.prj for coordinate system information.
attr.attrdefs: Calculated using Central Valley Hydrologic Model (CVHM) / MODPATH

attr.attrdef: Average groundwater age at well screen of 100 feet based on CVHM/MODPATH simulations. File is an ASCII array with header information for number of columns and rows, lower left corner coordinates, and cellsize. See array_projection_information.prj for coordinate system information.
attr.attrdefs: Calculated using Central Valley Hydrologic Model (CVHM) / MODPATH

attr.attrdefs: U.S. Department of Agriculture, Soil survey geographic (SSURGO) database (2014) and Wieczorek (2014)

attr.attrdef: Average porosity (percent). File is an ASCII array with header information for number of columns and rows, lower left corner coordinates, and cellsize. See array_projection_information.prj for coordinate system information.
attr.attrdefs: U.S. Department of Agriculture, Soil survey geographic (SSURGO) database (2014) and Wieczorek (2014)

attr.attrdef: Area and depth weighted average percent silt. File is an ASCII array with header information for number of columns and rows, lower left corner coordinates, and cellsize. See array_projection_information.prj for coordinate system information.
attr.attrdefs: U.S. Department of Agriculture, Soil survey geographic (SSURGO) database (2014) and Wieczorek (2014)

attr.attrdef: Annual Precipitation (mm). File is an ASCII array with header information for number of columns and rows, lower left corner coordinates, and cellsize. See array_projection_information.prj for coordinate system information.
attr.attrdefs: R. J. Hijmans, S. E. Cameron, J. L. Parra, P. G. Jones and A. Jarvis (2005)

attr.attrdef: Percent land use as natural or water in 1990. File is an ASCII array with header information for number of columns and rows, lower left corner coordinates, and cellsize. See array_projection_information.prj for coordinate system information.
attr.attrdefs: J. H. Viers and others (2012)

attr.attrdef: CVHM model textural zone (10: Redding, 11: Western Sacramento, 12: Eastern Sacramento, 20: Tracey/Delta Mendota, 21: Westwide, 22: Northern San Joaquin, 23: Chowchilla-Madera, 24: Kings, 30: Tulare/Kern). File is an ASCII array with header information for number of columns and rows, lower left corner coordinates, and cellsize. See array_projection_information.prj for coordinate system information.
attr.attrdefs: C. C. e. Faunt (2009)

attr.attrdef: Depth below ground surface of 60 year old water, predicted by groundwater age lumped parameter model and interpolated by kriging. File is an ASCII array with header information for number of columns and rows, lower left corner coordinates, and cellsize. See array_projection_information.prj for coordinate system information.
attr.attrdefs: B. C. Jurgens, J. K. Böhlke and S. M. Eberts (2012) and B. C. Jurgens, J. K. Böhlke, L. J. Kauffman, K. Belitz and B. K. Esser (2016)

attr.attrdef: Low value for range in depth to the seasonally high water table (ft). File is an ASCII array with header information for number of columns and rows, lower left corner coordinates, and cellsize. See array_projection_information.prj for coordinate system information.
attr.attrdefs: U.S. Department of Agriculture, U.S. general soil map (STATSGO2) (2014) and Wolock (1997)

attr.attrdef: Percent of area with soil identified as hydrologic group C. File is an ASCII array with header information for number of columns and rows, lower left corner coordinates, and cellsize. See array_projection_information.prj for coordinate system information.
attr.attrdefs: U.S. Department of Agriculture, Soil survey geographic (SSURGO) database (2014) and Wieczorek (2014)

attr.attrdef: Normalized distance (permil, ‰) from valley axis to valley wall. File is an ASCII array with header information for number of columns and rows, lower left corner coordinates, and cellsize. See array_projection_information.prj for coordinate system information.
attr.attrdefs: K. R. McPherson and T. Johnson (2016) and M. K. Landon, K. Belitz, B. C. Jurgens, J. T. Kulongoski and T. D. Johnson (2010)

attr.attrdef: CVHM-estimated depth to water table, Spring 2000 (ft). File is an ASCII array with header information for number of columns and rows, lower left corner coordinates, and cellsize. See array_projection_information.prj for coordinate system information.
attr.attrdefs: C. C. e. Faunt (2009)

attr.attrdef: Vertical water flux through bottom of upper active CVHM model layer, Feb. 2000, m3 /d, CVHM. File is an ASCII array with header information for number of columns and rows, lower left corner coordinates, and cellsize. See array_projection_information.prj for coordinate system information.
attr.attrdefs: C. C. e. Faunt (2009)

attr.attrdef: Vertical water flux through bottom of upper active CVHM model layer, Sep. 2000, m3 /d, CVHM. File is an ASCII array with header information for number of columns and rows, lower left corner coordinates, and cellsize. See array_projection_information.prj for coordinate system information.
attr.attrdefs: C. C. e. Faunt (2009)

attr.attrdef: Sum of Fert_N_farm_kg, Fert_N_urban_kg, and Atmos_N_kg (kg). File is an ASCII array with header information for number of columns and rows, lower left corner coordinates, and cellsize. See array_projection_information.prj for coordinate system information.
attr.attrdefs: Calculated value

attr.attrdef: Normalized unsaturated zone nitrogen load to water table (0-100%), from mass balance of selected GNLM variables for 1975. File is an ASCII array with header information for number of columns and rows, lower left corner coordinates, and cellsize. See array_projection_information.prj for coordinate system information.
attr.attrdefs: Calculated value

attr.attrdef: Kriged depth to bottom of screened interval of 50 feet. File is an ASCII array with header information for number of columns and rows, lower left corner coordinates, and cellsize. See array_projection_information.prj for coordinate system information.
attr.attrdefs: B. Jurgens (2016)

attr.attrdef: Kriged depth to bottom of screened interval of 100 feet. File is an ASCII array with header information for number of columns and rows, lower left corner coordinates, and cellsize. See array_projection_information.prj for coordinate system information.

attr.attrdefs: B. Jurgens (2016)

attr.attrdefs: B. Jurgens (2016)

attr.attrdefs: B. Jurgens (2016)

attr.attrdef: Kriged depth to bottom of screened interval of 500 feet. File is an ASCII array with header information for number of columns and rows, lower left corner coordinates, and cellsize. See array_projection_information.prj for coordinate system information.
attr.attrdefs: B. Jurgens (2016)

attr.attrdef: Kriged depth to bottom of screened interval of 600 feet. File is an ASCII array with header information for number of columns and rows, lower left corner coordinates, and cellsize. See array_projection_information.prj for coordinate system information.
attr.attrdefs: B. Jurgens (2016)

attr.attrdef: Kriged depth to bottom of screened interval of 700 feet. File is an ASCII array with header information for number of columns and rows, lower left corner coordinates, and cellsize. See array_projection_information.prj for coordinate system information.
attr.attrdefs: B. Jurgens (2016)

attr.attrdef: Kriged depth to bottom of screened interval of 800 feet. File is an ASCII array with header information for number of columns and rows, lower left corner coordinates, and cellsize. See array_projection_information.prj for coordinate system information.
attr.attrdefs: B. Jurgens (2016)

attr.attrdef: Kriged depth to bottom of screened interval of 900 feet. File is an ASCII array with header information for number of columns and rows, lower left corner coordinates, and cellsize. See array_projection_information.prj for coordinate system information.

attr.attrdef: Kriged depth to bottom of screened interval of 1000 feet. File is an ASCII array with header information for number of columns and rows, lower left corner coordinates, and cellsize. See array_projection_information.prj for coordinate system information.

attr.attrdef: Kriged depth to bottom of screened interval of 1600 feet. File is an ASCII array with header information for number of columns and rows, lower left corner coordinates, and cellsize. See array_projection_information.prj for coordinate system information.
attr.attrdefs: B. Jurgens (2016)

attr.attrdef: Percent coarse texture soil (CVTM) in upper active CVHM model layer. File is an ASCII array with header information for number of columns and rows, lower left corner coordinates, and cellsize. See array_projection_information.prj for coordinate system information.
attr.attrdefs: C. C. e. Faunt (2009)

attr.attrdef: Average annual precipitation minus potential evapotranspiration (in/year) for the period 1971 - 2000. File is an ASCII array with header information for number of columns and rows, lower left corner coordinates, and cellsize. See array_projection_information.prj for coordinate system information.
attr.attrdefs: U.S. Geological Survey (2016)

attr.attrdef: Model predicted probability of anoxic groundwater, dissolved oxygen concentration less than 0.5 mg/L at 91.44 m below ground surface (wells assigned value for deep zone). File is an ASCII array with header information for number of columns and rows, lower left corner coordinates, and cellsize. See array_projection_information.prj for coordinate system information.
attr.attrdefs: C. Z. Rosecrans, J. Gronberg and B. T. Nolan (2016)

attr.attrdef: Model predicted probability of anoxic groundwater, dissolved oxygen concentration less than 0.5 mg/L at 45.72 m below ground surface (wells assigned value for shallow zone). File is an ASCII array with header information for number of columns and rows, lower left corner coordinates, and cellsize. See array_projection_information.prj for coordinate system information.
attr.attrdefs: C. Z. Rosecrans, J. Gronberg and B. T. Nolan (2016)

attr.attrdef: Model predicted probability of manganese concentration greater than 50 µg/L at 91.44 m below ground surface (wells assigned value for deep zone). File is an ASCII array with header information for number of columns and rows, lower left corner coordinates, and cellsize. See array_projection_information.prj for coordinate system information.
attr.attrdefs: C. Z. Rosecrans, J. Gronberg and B. T. Nolan (2016)

attr.attrdef: Model predicted probability of manganese concentration greater than 50 µg/L at 45.72 m below ground surface (wells assigned value for shallow zone). File is an ASCII array with header information for number of columns and rows, lower left corner coordinates, and cellsize. See array_projection_information.prj for coordinate system information.
attr.attrdefs: C. Z. Rosecrans, J. Gronberg and B. T. Nolan (2016)

attr.attrdef: Mean annual natural groundwater recharge (mm/year). Average of values within buffer. File is an ASCII array with header information for number of columns and rows, lower left corner coordinates, and cellsize. See array_projection_information.prj for coordinate system information.
attr.attrdefs: D. M. Wolock (2003)

attr.attrdef: Distance to river with stream order &gt; 3 (m). File is an ASCII array with header information for number of columns and rows, lower left corner coordinates, and cellsize. See array_projection_information.prj for coordinate system information.
attr.attrdefs: K. R. McPherson and T. Johnson (2016) and M. K. Landon, K. Belitz, B. C. Jurgens, J. T. Kulongoski and T. D. Johnson (2010)

attr.attrdef: Length of screened interval for deep zone, or PBot_krig – PTop_krig. File is an ASCII array with header information for number of columns and rows, lower left corner coordinates, and cellsize. See array_projection_information.prj for coordinate system information.
attr.attrdefs: Calculated value

attr.attrdef: Length of screened interval for shallow zone, or PBot_krig – PTop_krig. File is an ASCII array with header information for number of columns and rows, lower left corner coordinates, and cellsize. See array_projection_information.prj for coordinate system information.
attr.attrdefs: Calculated value

attr.attrdef: Use of water at well. Assigned as “P=public supply” or “H=private” based on Depth_zone. All wells from Ransom et al. (2016) were assigned “H=private”. No file for this variable is provided.
attr.attrdefs: National Water Information System data available on the World Wide Web (USGS Water Data for the Nation)

overview.eaover: The entity and attribute information provided here describes the tabular data associated with the data set. Please review the detailed descriptions that are provided (the individual attribute descriptions) for information on the values that appear as fields/table entries of the data set.
overview.eadetcit: The entity and attribute information was generated by the individual and/or agency identified as the originator of the data set. Please review the rest of the metadata record for additional details and information.

cntaddr.address: Denver Federal Center, Building 810, Mail Stop 302

distinfo.distliab: Distributor assumes no liability for misuse of data.

digtinfo.formcont: This WinZip file contains the ASCII test files as well as the associated metadata file.

stdorder.fees: None. No fees are applicable for obtaining the data set.

metainfo.metstdn: Content Standard for Digital Geospatial Metadata
